Slumped on the desk with her messy dull hair covering her eyes, Karen Matthews looks defeated as she bombarded by questions over daughter Shannon. 
The game was up - and Karen, who had gone from worried mum to an arrested suspect, knew it. 
Grainy footage, which BBC bosses used as a basis for latest drama The Moorside, paints a disturbing picture of the mum-of-seven - who easily admits she lied to police, her family and the nation. 
Her arrest was a crushing blow to the Dewsbury community who worked tirelessly to search for nine-year-old Shannon in 2008. Karen Matthews interview with the police Karen Matthews interview with the police 
And, in chilling interviews Karen shows complete disregard for daughter's welfare, looking more sorry for herself. 
When she is asked "What did you hope to achieve [from the plot]" bleary-eyed Karen fails to understand the meaning of the sentence. She admits, in a slurry voice, that she couldn't tell police where Shannon was because "everyone would have a go" at her. Shannon Matthews (Photo: PA) Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Karen Matthews is interviewed by West Yorkshire Police Share this video Watch Next Karen Matthews (Photo: Nigel Bennett) 
She goes on to admit that she knew Shannon was Mick Donovan at that point and not missing. 
As controversial new drama The Moorside airs, a nation has remembered the sad reality behind the gripping BBC show - but the cruel facts surrounding the kidnap will shock even the most hardened viewer. 
Designed to be a celebration of the Dewsbury estate's ability to pull together in a crisis, The Moorside has divided the country with its depiction of Shannon's 2008 kidnap, with the Matthews family branding the drama "sick". The heartbreaking list of rules drawn up her captors (Photo: PA) Karen Matthews in 2008 - she later became "Britain's most hated mum" (Photo: PA) Read More 
But, as people will remember, the harrowing truth behind the Sheridan Smith drama is more than "sick" - with the innocent nine-year-old being lured away to her step-dad's uncle's house with the promise of a trip to the seaside. 
Instead she was tethered to a bed, like a dog, for 24 days. 
And that plot was masterminded by the woman she was meant to trust the most in the world - her mother. A list of rules, presumably written by Micheal Donovan give some clue as to what Shannon did to occupy herself during those long 24 days. Read More Inside the house of horrors where Shannon Matthews was held captive tethered to a bed for 24 days 
The heartbreaking note reads: "Rules. You must not make any noise or bang your feet 
"You must not go near the windows. You must not get anything or do anything without me been here (sic). Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Take a sneak peek at Episode two of The Moorside Share this video Donovan was later jailed for eight years (Photo: PA) Read More Pictured then and now: Moorside's Karen Matthews, Craig Meehan, Julie Bushby and more 
"Keep the TV volume (low) only up to 8 or lower. You can play the Super Mario games and you can play some DVDs and you can play the CD music." 
It is signed off with the initials I.P.U - which is thought to stand for 'I promise you' - a threat Karen used against Shannon. 
And, here is the dingy sparsely furnished room in the top floor flat rented by her stepdad's uncle - where Shannon was kept, after being lured away from safety by Donovan, who told the innocent girl she was going to the seaside. The bedroom where Shannon was held for a nail-biting 24 days (Photo: Daily Mirror) A heartbreaking scene of a keyboard was left in the bedroom (Photo: Daily Mirror) In an horrible twist Shannon appeared to have been given a book on travelling safely (Photo: Daily Mirror) Read More Ghoulish Karen Matthews Tours of estate where Shannon was kidnapped offered by locals for Â£15 
In damning evidence which went on to convict Donovan and mum Karen - disturbing pictures of where Shannon was held were shown to the 2008 jury, shocking the nation with their depravity. 
For 24 nail-biting days, this dingy bedroom with its threadbare carpets and dirty walls was the most hunted hideaway in Britain. 
There was even a heartbreaking list of rules for poor Shannon to live by, including staying away from the windows and keeping the TV volume low. 
Day in, day out increasingly worried police drew a blank as they looked for Shannon in the biggest search since the Yorkshire Ripper. Read More The rope used to tether tiny Shannon to a double bed (Photo: PA) The dingy lounge - Shannon was told to stay away from the windows (Photo: Matthew Pover) Donovan tethered Shannon to the bed and shoved the child under his double bed when the police came to visit (Photo: Matthew Pover) 
But all the time the answer lay here just a mile from her home where the youngster was being held against her will in a two-bedroom top flat. 
The scruffy bedroom containing cheap wooden furniture was the former sleeping area for Donovan's two daughters who were taken into care before the kidnap. 
No one knows how poor Shannon spent the lonely hours of her alleged kidnap. (Photo: PA) Officers strip Donovan's flat bare after the discovery of Shannon (Photo: PA) 
But a handful of clues in these pictures of the room show how she may have occupied herself as the massive search went on around her. 
An electronic keyboard and, bizarrely, a glue gun lie on top of a metal framed double bunk. 
Underneath there is a CD by Busted, one of Shannon's favourite bands, and a leaflet giving details of a range of Sold Out action PC games. 
Near a smoke alarm case there is a copy of Arrive Alive, a colourful highway code book for youngsters. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
